channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: El Chapo, Mexican Drug Kingpin, Is Extradited to U.S.
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, after his recapture last year in the city of Los Mochis, Sinaloa, Mexico.
item.description: In an about-face for the Mexican government, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was turned over to American officials on Thursday night.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Riot Police Try to Quell Continuing Violence in Brazilian Prison
item.description: Specially equipped police officers entered a prison near the city of Natal as rival gangs battled each other with metal bars and wooden clubs in scenes reminiscent of medieval warfare.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: Gambia’s New President Is Sworn In as Troops Enter the Country
item.media:description: Adama Barrow, the newly elected president of Gambia, after being sworn in on Thursday in a ceremony at an embassy in neighboring Senegal.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Yahya Jammeh, Gambia’s leader for 22 years, is refusing to make way for the newly elected president, Adama Barrow, who has yet to enter his own country as president.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Julian Assange Repeats Offer of Extradition to U.S.
item.media:description: Julian Assange on the balcony of the Ecuadorean embassy in London last year.
item.description: The founder of WikiLeaks said on Thursday he said he would go if his rights were “protected,” though he is not under public indictment by the United States.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Martin McGuinness, an I.R.A Leader Who Later Embraced Ulster Politics, Says He’ll Retire
item.description: Mr. McGuinness, who resigned as deputy first minister of Northern Ireland earlier this month after an internal political dispute, announced his retirement on health grounds.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: In India, Tension Over Traditions Perilous to Animals and Humans Alike
item.media:description: Indians in Chennai protested a ban on a bull wrestling festival in Chennai on Thursday, paralyzing the streets.
item.description: Thousands of Indians are protesting a ban on a bull-wrestling tradition in Tamil Nadu, but it isn’t the only cultural tradition coming under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Was Ending the Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Justified?
item.media:description: The aircraft that disappeared, photographed over Poland earlier in 2014.
item.description: A multigovernment decision to stop the search, already the longest and most expensive in aviation history, raises ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Right-Wing Hoteliers in Japan Anger China With Radical Historical Views
item.media:description: Toshio Motoya, president of the APA Group, in Tokyo in 2015.
item.description: Fumiko and Toshio Motoya, founders of the APA Group and defenders of Japan’s wartime conduct, provoked threats of a boycott over a book promoted at their chain.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Trump Renews Vow for Jerusalem Embassy, a Gift of Uncertain Value
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Tel Aviv, where other countries have their embassies.
item.description: Palestinians in the West Bank protested the idea, which even many hard-line Israelis are not keen to embrace, seeing it as a catalyst to more fighting.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: C.I.A. Torture Detailed in Newly Disclosed Documents
item.media:description: Central Intelligence Agency headquarters in McLean, Va.
item.description: The material sheds additional light on the torture program as the future of the Senate’s classified full report on it hangs in the balance with the Obama presidency ending.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK, JAMES RISEN and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: What in the World: When an Airline Suffered Misfortune, Some Looked for a Goat
item.description: The ritual slaughter of animals is common in Pakistan, but the airport sacrifice of a goat after a deadly plane crash still met with ridicule.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Intercepted Russian Communications Part of Inquiry Into Trump Associates
item.media:description: Paul Manafort, Donald J. Trump’s former campaign chairman, at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: It is not clear whether the communications had anything to do with Donald J. Trump or his campaign.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, MATTHEW ROSENBERG, ADAM GOLDMAN and MATT APUZZO
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Supreme Court Justice Helping to Oversee Brazil Graft Inquiry Dies in Plane Crash
item.description: The Supreme Court justice, Teori Zavascki, had earned a reputation as a judge prepared to curb abuses of power by influential lawmakers and business leaders.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: A Clown and a Correspondent Join the Global Elite
item.media:description: What look like massive beach balls hanging from the ceiling are part of a project called Aerocene, led by the artist Tomás Saraceno, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
item.description: Ben Hubbard, a Mideast correspondent for The Times, tags along with his wife, a storyteller who was invited to Davos as a “Cultural Leader.”
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Despite Syria Cease-Fire, U.N. Says, Aid Isn’t Reaching Besieged Areas
item.description: Armed opposition groups and government forces “are routinely doing what they can, all of them it seems, to avoid us helping women, children, wounded on the other side,” an official said.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: When Journalism Meets Civil Disobedience
item.media:description: At Cédric Herrou’s habitat in the foothills of the Alps outside Nice, France, where African migrants hid last September before crossing the border.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: I had gotten a decent man in trouble while pursuing a good story.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Theresa May Says Britain Will Lead a New Era of Free Trade
item.description: It was a jarring note from the leader of a country leaving the world’s largest free-trade group. She also urged the Davos elite to seriously address inequality.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trilobites: Fishing for Clues to Solve Namibia’s Fairy Circle Mystery
item.media:description: A fairy circle in the NamibRand Nature Reserve in the Namib Desert.
item.description: The new study suggests that both termites and plants may be jointly responsible for forming fairy circle landscapes in Namibia.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Philippine Police Are Accused of Killing South Korean Businessman
item.media:description: The chief of the Philippine National Police, Ronald dela Rosa, left, with President Rodrigo Duterte in Manila on Thursday.
item.description: Officers seized Jee Ick-joo under the pretense of a drug raid last year and later extorted money from his family, the Justice Department of the Philippines said.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: At Least 20 Firefighters Killed in Tehran High-Rise Collapse
item.description: The 17-story Plasco Building, one of the Iranian capital’s oldest and most prominent skyscrapers, crumpled into a smoldering heap as millions watched on state TV.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: Wife of Detained Chinese Rights Lawyer Seeks Angela Merkel’s Help
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong demanding the release of the rights lawyer Jiang Tianyong in December. Mr. Jiang has been in custody since November, but the Chinese authorities have not disclosed where.
item.description: The rights lawyer Jiang Tianyong once met the German chancellor in Beijing. Now his wife is hoping that Ms. Merkel can push Beijing to disclose his whereabouts.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Avalanche in Italy Buries Hotel, Leaving up to 30 Missing
item.media:description: As many as 30 people were reported missing at the hotel.
item.media:credit: Alpine and Speleological Rescue Team, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The disaster came after earthquakes struck the region on Wednesday, prompting officials to close schools and the subway system in Rome as a precaution.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Persecuted Minority in Myanmar Is Escalating Its Armed Insurgency
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, on Wednesday. About 65,000 are believed to have come from Myanmar since October, joining about a half-million who had already arrived.
item.description: Some analysts fear that turning the Rohingya into a transnational Muslim cause may draw foreign jihadists to Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK, ELLEN BARRY and MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rights Groups Ask China to Free Tibetan Education Advocate
item.media:description: Tashi Wangchuk, a Tibetan entrepreneur and education advocate, at his home in Yushu, China, in 2015.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The Tibetan, Tashi Wangchuk, was detained and accused of inciting separatism nearly a year ago after speaking to The New York Times for a documentary video and two articles.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Mexican Student Fatally Shoots Himself in Classroom After Wounding Four
item.media:description: Outside the Colegio Americano del Noreste in Monterrey, Mexico, on Wednesday after a teenage student shot several students and a teacher and killed himself.
item.description: The motives of a 15-year-old who opened fire in Monterrey were unknown, and investigators were looking into where he got the weapon.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Isidro Baldenegro, Mexican Environmental Activist, Is Shot to Death
item.media:description: Isidro Baldenegro López in 2003.
item.description: Mr. Baldenegro, winner of the Goldman Environmental Prize, defended the western Sierra Madre’s old-growth forests against powerful local strongmen.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: In a Blow to Prosecutor, South Korean Court Blocks Arrest of Samsung Group Leader
item.media:description: Jay Y. Lee, the leader of Samsung, leaving court in Seoul on Wednesday.
item.description: A justice rejected a request to issue a warrant for Jay Y. Lee, but the de facto Samsung chief can still be indicted if a special prosecutor decides to pursue bribery allegations.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Iraqi Forces Take Eastern Mosul From Islamic State
item.media:description: American military personnel in Iraq during a battle with Islamic State militants at the University of Mosul on Wednesday.
item.description: The announcement came three months after government troops, aided by American air support and military advisers, began an assault to retake the city.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trudeau Hits the Road, and Crowds and Questions Follow
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with supporters in Kingston, Ontario, on Jan. 12. Mr. Trudeau has set off on a nationwide tour that includes town hall-style events.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: With the Canadian prime minister’s image in need of some polishing, his January town-hall tour has all the earmarks of a campaign to reconnect with voters.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Suicide Attack at Military Camp in Mali Kills Scores
item.media:description: Soldiers attended to casualties on Wednesday after a suicide attack at a Malian camp where soldiers and former fighters who reached a peace agreement with the government in 2015 had been working together to try to stabilize the region.
item.description: Many of the victims at the camp in Gao were soldiers and former rebel fighters who have been trying to work together to stabilize Mali’s restive north.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Death Toll in Mistaken Bombing of Camp in Nigeria Climbs to 70
item.description: The number killed in an errant bombing by a Nigerian military fighter jet on Tuesday included at least nine aid workers, humanitarian groups said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Germany’s Extreme Right Challenges Guilt Over Nazi Past
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, left, at a rally for Alternative for Germany, in Dresden on Tuesday.
item.description: Björn Höcke, a star in the Alternative for Germany party, has found success questioning national regret over the Holocaust and the country’s Nazi crimes.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB and MAX FISHER

item.title: United Nations Memo: In South Sudan, Mass Killings, Rapes and the Limits of U.S. Diplomacy
item.media:description: Samantha Power, center, the American ambassador to the United Nations, and members of the Security Council visited displaced people in Wau, South Sudan, last year.
item.description: Samantha Power, the ambassador to the United Nations, is known for advocating diplomacy to prevent atrocities, but poor timing has hampered efforts to avert a catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Villager and Israeli Police Officer Die in Clash at Bedouin Hamlet
item.media:description: Israeli police officers detaining a man during clashes after a protest against house demolitions in the Bedouin village of Umm al-Hiran on Wednesday.
item.description: There were conflicting accounts about events in Umm al-Hiran, a Negev village where homes were slated for demolition.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel

item.title: Russia Extends Edward Snowden’s Asylum
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden speaking to an audience in Massachusetts during a live video webcast in 2016.
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.description: Moscow said the former N.S.A. contractor, who was granted asylum in 2013, would be allowed to remain for “a couple more years.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: China Cancels 103 Coal Plants, Mindful of Smog and Wasted Capacity
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Shanxi, China, in 2015. The government has canceled 103 coal plants that were planned or under construction, eliminating 120 gigawatts of future coal-fired capacity.
item.description: The dropped projects include dozens already under construction, even though existing plants can already generate far more power than the country needs.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere: On Taking Gay Rights From Taipei to Beijing: Don’t Call It a ‘Movement’
item.media:description: Lai Jeng-jer, a gay rights activist from Taiwan, at Two Cities, the cafe he opened after moving to Beijing in 2012. Before that, he had run a pioneering gay-themed bookstore in Taipei, Taiwan’s capital.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Lai Jeng-jer, a leader on gay rights in Taiwan who now lives in Beijing, discusses the progress he’s seen on the mainland, as well as the limitations.
item.dc:creator: YURU CHENG and AMY CHANG CHIEN
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: President’s Term Running Out, Gambia Shudders as He Refuses to Quit
item.description: The president’s refusal to accept his electoral loss to Adama Barrow, after initially doing so, threatens to drag the nation into a bloody standoff.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China’s Chief Justice Rejects an Independent Judiciary, and Reformers Wince
item.media:description: Chief Justice Zhou Qiang at the National People’s Congress in Beijing in March. A recent speech by the chief justice was seen as a nod to China’s strict political climate, set by President Xi Jinping.
item.description: Zhou Qiang denounced the “trap” of “Western” ideology, dismaying some liberal-minded observers of the Chinese legal system who had seen him as an encouraging figure.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S.-Trained Official May Shape China’s Response to Trump on Trade
item.media:description: Liu He in Beijing in 2010. As the top economic adviser to China’s president, Xi Jinping, Mr. Liu has sought to make China’s growth less reliant on rising debt and public spending.
item.description: Liu He, the top economic adviser to President Xi Jinping, has argued for more open markets. But his agenda could be overwhelmed by fears of fallout from a trade war.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Britain’s Soccer Sex Abuse Scandal
item.description: In institution after institution, a pattern of exploitation of society’s most vulnerable members has emerged.
item.dc:creator: SARFRAZ MANZOOR

item.title: Editorial: Freezing to Death at Europe’s Door
item.media:description: Migrants inside a warehouse near Belgrade’s main railway station, in Serbia, on Tuesday.
item.description: Failure to prepare for the winter threatens the lives of thousands of refugees.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Voting Should Be Mandatory
item.media:description: Voters in Canberra, Australia, in July. Around three-quarters of Australians have consistently supported compulsory voting.
item.description: Compulsory elections are won in the center. Extremist politicians can’t get traction.
item.dc:creator: WALEED ALY
